The New England Patriots seemed to be playing football on some other planet this season.
The Pats have won 13 games, lost none and are on a course to have the first undefeated season since the Watergate era.
On Sunday, they play the New York Jets who are, well, not quite as good as that.
But the Jets are the team that began the season by blowing a whistle on the Pats for taping their opponent's sideline signals.
Will New England's vow to dominate and subdue be undone by their passion for payback?
Will the Jets be able to sell the too disappointing season with a single semi-miraculous win?
Who says Howard Cosell is gone?
Not as long as we're around.
The biggest Jets fan that we know of is Gary Vaynerchuk, proprietor of the Wine Library in New Jersey and Winelibrarytv - all one word - dot com.
He joins us from New York.
Gary, welcome back.
It's good to be on.
The opoint spread is 24-and-a-half points, and it ain't in the Jets' favor.
You know, we're going to cover that spread obviously very easily, and that's because the mother is on our side.
And the mother I'm speaking of is Mother Nature.
It seems like a Nor'easter is well it's on its way to Foxborough for this game.
Yeah.
And hopefully, with those weather conditions, we'll be able to stay within those 24-and-a-half points.
Well, but I didn't know the New England Patriots know how to play in that kind of whether.
I mean, they're from Boston.
But they've become very prima donna.
I mean, this is one of the great franchises of all time, and they've been built traditionally on running attack.
And now, they don't run the ball at all, which, you know, they may run the ball three, four, five times a game.
It's pretty scary.
Oh, right.
I see where you're getting at.
So when the weather gets a little bit hairy, it's a little bit tougher to throw the balls.
I mean, you know, Randy Moss is not the kind of guy who's going to out there and love the snow.
He's going to be, you know, keeping his hands in his pockets.
He's a, you know, prima donna receiver.
So I'm a little bit confident that, you know, the Jets - this is their Super Bowl, like it is for everybody else.
The Patriots are on a mission to be the greatest team that anybody has ever seen, and so, hopefully, they'll be up for it.
But obviously, the Patriots are not huge fans of the Jets, so they'll be up for it as well.
Gary, you are absolutely the best fan anybody has ever seen.
I know.
I've never heard anybody with a greater, more eloquent gift for turning a 24 - 24-and-a-half or whatever it is point spread into a positive advantage in this case.
Well, this is what happens when you taste thousands of bad wines a year and you've got to kind of put some sort of spin on it to tell people that it's not hogwash.
When was the last time you missed a play in a Jets game?
Let me put it that way.
When we were talking about this, you know, we were drinking wine a couple of months back and, well, I have not missed a physical play of a Jets game in 13 years.
So I bleed green - there's nothing in the world that I hate more than the New England Patriots when it comes to that mindset of football.
But this would be absolutely a great bragging rights win for the Jets.
But I'll be honest with you, I think the Patriots would be very well off in losing a regular season game.
I have a weird, sneaky feeling they're going to - go undefeated and then get stunned in the playoffs.
That's what the Indianapolis Colts have to hope, isn't it?
Mm-hmm, it is.
Now, you haven't missed a play in 13 years.
Mm-hmm.
You never go to the bathroom during the game?
Before the game and then whatever it takes.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I mean, it's scary - when we're talking about scary things, the day after my wedding, you know, during the busiest day of the year at Wine Library.
I mean, crazy things that have not kept me away.
I mean, I have nightmares during the season that I've actually missed part of the football game.

It's kind of scary.

Southwest China was rocked again today.
A strong aftershock leveled tens of thousands of homes that had survived the May 12 earthquake.
The aftershock reached a magnitude of at least 6.0.
China's National Seismic Network said it was the strongest one in nearly two weeks since the original quake.
NPR's Andrea Hsu spent the day in the farming village of Yongan, where despite widespread devastation, life is resuming.
(Soundbite of splashing)
(Chinese spoken)
I first spot 58-year-old Chen Shengmin from the road…
(Soundbite of car horn honking)
…as he's plowing through a muddy field with his ox.
Two weeks ago, the day before the earthquake, this scene would have been unremarkable.
It is rice planting season, after all, and this part of China is known for its fertile soil.
But today, the backdrop for Chen's work is one of utter destruction.
Brick and cement homes sit ripped apart by the earthquake.
(Chinese spoken)
Still, Chen tells me, now that we've harvested the canola, we need to plant rice.
We can't just sit around doing nothing.
We have to get on with our lives.
That seems all the more difficult when I learn that Chen lost his 2-and-a-half-year-old grandson in the quake.
The boy was crushed to death by falling debris.
Chen and his entire village are sleeping in makeshift tents.
When I ask about rebuilding their homes, he scoffs.
